subject: Re: [junit] How many aspects a particular test method should  test???
msgSnippet: ... I don t know why I didn t see it before (well, yes I do, I wasn t looking!), but the example method simplifies to: public void someMethod(int someParam)
messageBody:
At 9/13/2005 04:27 AM, you wrote:
>On Sunday 11 September 2005 20:31, xll_ll_ll_ll_ll_llx wrote:
> > Hi all,
> > I am really really new with JUnit. Do excuse me if this question is
> > too simple that it irritated you. OK so here is my confusion:
> >
> > The method I want to test is something like this:
> >
> > public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException
> > {
> > if(someParam!=1||someParam!=2)
> > throw invalidParamException
> >
> > someParam++;
> > }
> >
> > Now this method will test someParam passed to it and if it gets stuck
> > in the IF statement will throw exception else update someParam. Now
> > what I wanna know is that the test method that I write to test a
> > method like this should I be writing one test method that tests both
> > whether exception is thrown correctly as well as someParam updated
> > correctly. OR
> > I should be writing one test method that tests for the exception and
> > another that tests whether someParam is being updated appropriately.
>
>At least two methods.
>
>Note that the update to `someParam` is pointless in the code you
>show. `someParam` is a local variable (specifically, an argument)
>of primitive type (int); when someMethod exits, someParam evaporates.
>
>--
>Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
>Logic is rational /re/construction. Life is construction.

I don't know why I didn't see it before (well, yes I do, I wasn't
looking!), but the example method simplifies to:
public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException {
throw new invalidParamException();
}
So it's trivial to test! (Not to mention just plain trivial, but that's
the danger of trying to illustrate a point with "code". I'm sure that if
one were to attempt to write a test for some observable behavior in place
of the "someParam++;" (say, a call to some other method), even the
original author would discover the problem with the condition as written.

The problem with this type of code and the lack of tests is when someone
changes the condition and the previously unreachable code (but not
"unreachable" in a simple, static sense) can then be executed. I know I've
been bitten by that bug in the past.

-Rob
